revision.text:
{{Italic title}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Nightmare on Drug Street | image = | caption = | alt = | director = Traci Wald Donat | writer = George Larrimore | producer = | starring = [[Raymond Cruz]]
Joleen Lutz
[[Adam Jeffries]] | music = | cinematography = | editing = | released = | studio = | distributor = Twin Tower | runtime = 39 minutes{{cite web|url=http://people.com/archive/picks-and-pans-review-nightmare-on-drug-street-vol-31-no-14/|title=Picks and Pans Review: Nightmare on Drug Street|publisher=''[[People (magazine)|People]]''|author=Ralph Novak|date=10 April 1989|access-date=13 December 2016}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = }} '''''A Nightmare on Drug Street''''' is a 1989 [[direct-to-video]] [[Substance abuse|anti-drug]] [[short film]] directed by Traci Wald Donat.{{cite web|url=http://dangerousminds.net/comments/nightmare_on_drug_street_no_pizza_no_pizza_no_pizza_no_pizza_no_pizza |title=Nightmare on Drug Street: 'No Pizza, No Pizza, No Pizza, No Pizza, No Pizza...'|location=Dangerous Minds|author=Richard Metzger|date=2 January 2013|access-date=13 December 2016}} The film introduces three young characters, Felipe ([[Raymond Cruz]]), Jill ([[Joleen Lutz]]), and Eddie ([[Adam Jeffries]]), who are now dead. They each died at around the same time, and now exist only as spirits in some sort of dark purgatory. The cause of their respective deaths is that they each made the mistake of getting involved with drugs, a decision they now regret. The three then proceed to narrate each other's stories about how and why they got involved with drugs, and how it ultimately led to their untimely endings. Jill narrates Felipe's story. Felipe was a 17 year old senior, and a basketball athlete. However, he smoked [[marijuana|dope]] because he heard college kids did it, and he drank [[beer]] because his dad drank. One evening, Felipe, while under the influence of both, decided to borrow the family car without permission, and go on a [[Driving under the influence|joyride]] around town, taking his best friend, who was also under the influence, and his reluctant younger brother along. However, Felipe's increasingly erratic behavior and near misses while driving, caused his younger brother to become fed up, and he demanded to be let out of the car, to which Felipe grudgingly obliged. Felipe's brother's life was thus, spared, however he was not spared the horror of witnessing the gruesome deaths of Felipe and his friend from an inevitable [[car crash|car wreck]] only a moment later. Eddie narrates Jill's story. Jill was a 14 year old high school student, who was quite shy. One evening, she had a party for all her classmates, where she met an attractive new student. This student took her on a walk outside alone, where he introduced her to [[cocaine]], as a mood enhancer. Jill was reluctant to try it, but the new student claimed it would one day be legalized. After she snorted an initial dose, Jill was enamored with the feeling it gave her, and quickly became addicted, thus beginning a major downward spiral. She began trading off all her money and possessions to [[drug dealers]] to obtain more cocaine, even resorting to stealing from family and friends, becoming increasingly and majorly depressed the whole way. Finally, one day after a bad but desperate trade with a sleazy dealer for another gram of cocaine, Jill finished it off quickly, and died that evening, by [[suicide]] from an [[Drug overdose|overdose]] of cocaine and unidentified pills. Felipe narrates Eddie's story. Eddie was an 11 year old, elementary school student, and aspiring scientist. One day, while at his friends' house, he was [[peer pressure|pressured by them]] to experiment with some [[crack cocaine]], and Eddie reluctantly tried a dose, and went home, where his mother sensed something about Eddie was off. To deflect any further parental suspicion, Eddie was instructed via telephone to smoke a second dose to undo the [[side effects|effects]] of the first one. That evening, at dinner, Eddie's mother and father both noticed something about him was still off, but they dismissed it as a cold or allergy. Suddenly, without warning, Eddie collapsed and died of [[cardiac arrest]], a result of the crack's effect on a congenital heart defect, that no one realized he had. After the three tell their stories, they give the viewer tips, on how to make smarter decisions to either avoid drugs altogether, and how to get help if started, so that the same fate doesn't await them. {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0185813}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nightmare on Drug Street, A}} [[Category:1980s short films]] [[Category:1989 films]] [[Category:American short films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Drug policy of the United States]] [[Category:Educational films]] {{short-film-stub}}

{{Infobox organization |name = Academy of Management |image = Aomlogo.jpg |size = 200 px |alt = Logo of the Academy of Management |caption = |motto = |formation = 1936 |type = [[Professional body]] |headquarters = [[Briarcliff Manor, New York]] |location = |membership = >19,000 in over 115 countries<ref>http://aom.org</ref> |language = |leader_title = President |leader_name = [[Mary Ann Glynn]] |website = http://aom.org }} The '''Academy of Management''' ('''AOM'''; '''the Academy''') is a [[professional association]] for [[scholars]] of [[management]] and [[organizations]] that was established in 1936.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://aom.org/About-AOM/History.aspx |title=AOM History |accessdate=2013-01-30 |format= |work= }}</ref> It publishes several [[academic journal]]s, organizes conferences, and provides others forums for management [[professor]]s and managers to communicate research and ideas.
Since 1994, the Academy has been headquartered on the [[Briarcliff Manor, New York]] campus of [[Pace University]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Pace University|url=http://aom.org/pace.aspx|publisher=Academy of Management|accessdate=March 3, 2015}}</ref>
== Divisions == Upon registration, members of the Academy are granted memberships in two of its 25 divisions and interest groups; they may then pay an additional fee to join more. Each division focuses on a certain aspect of management, and each division has its own governing officers. As of August 2015, these divisions and interest groups include:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://login.aomonline.org/aom.asp?id=18 |title=AoM Divisions and Interest Groups |accessdate=2008-05-06 |format= |work= }}</ref> {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * Business Policy and Strategy * Careers * Conflict Management * Critical Management Studies * Entrepreneurship * Gender & Diversity in Organizations * Health Care Management * Human Resources * International Management * Management Consulting * Management Education & Development * Management History * Management Spirituality and Religion * Managerial and Organizational Cognition * Operations Management * Organization and Management Theory * Organization Development and Change * Organizational Behavior * Organizational Communication and Information Systems * Organizations and The Natural Environment * Public and Nonprofit * Research Methods * Social Issues in Management * Strategizing Activities and Practices * Technology and Innovation Management }}
== Publications == The publications of the Academy include the following: [[File:AOM Journal Covers 2012.jpg|thumb|AOM Journal Covers 2012]] * ''[[Academy of Management Journal]]'' * ''[[Academy of Management Review]]'' * ''[[Academy of Management Perspectives]]'' (formerly ''Academy of Management Executive'') * ''[[Academy of Management Learning and Education]]'' * ''Academy of Management Annals'' * ''Academy of Management Discoveries''
The first three journals were ranked in the top 40 business journals in the world in 2006 by the ''[[Financial Times]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://business.queensu.ca/faculty_and_research/research_news/FTBEjournals.pdf |title=FT Tope 40 Journals – 2006 |accessdate=2008-05-06 |format= |work= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090824133014/http://business.queensu.ca/faculty_and_research/research_news/FTBEjournals.pdf |archivedate=2009-08-24 }}</ref>
== Conferences == The Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management draws more than 10,000 students, academics, scholars, and professionals in the scholarly management and organization space. It provides a forum for sharing research and expertise in all management disciplines through invited and competitive paper sessions, panels, symposia, workshops, speakers, and special programs for doctoral students.
The 77th Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management was held August 4–8, 2017, in Atlanta, GA.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aom.org/annualmeeting/ |title=Annual meeting |publisher=aom.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-05}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Human resources development]] * [[Human resource management]] * [[Industrial and organizational psychology]] * [[Industrial sociology]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://aom.org/}}

page.title: Academy of Performing Arts in Sarajevo

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Infobox university |image_name = |name = Academy of Performing Arts in Sarajevo |established = 1981 |type = [[Faculty (division)|Faculty]] |dean= Pjer Zalica |city = [[Sarajevo]] |state = |country = [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] |students = |staff= 30 |campus = [[urban area|Urban]] |website= [http://www.asu.unsa.ba/ www.asu.unsa.ba] |endowment= }} '''Academy of Performing Arts in Sarajevo''' ([[Bosnian language|Bosnian]]: ''Akademija scenskih umjentosti Sarajevo'') is a faculty within the [[University of Sarajevo]] in [[Sarajevo]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], dedicated to the [[performing arts]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.detail.de/artikel_archipelagos-academy-of-performing-arts-sarajevo_22467_En.htm/|title=Detail.de: ''Academy of Performing Arts in Sarajevo''(in Bosnian) [cited February 21, 2012]|publisher=|accessdate=10 October 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120106064826/http://www.detail.de/artikel_archipelagos-academy-of-performing-arts-sarajevo_22467_En.htm#|archive-date=2012-01-06|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
The Academy of Performing Arts in Sarajevo was officially opened in 1981 with the inaugural Department of [[Acting]]. This was followed by the opening of the Department of [[Theatre director|Directing]] in 1989, the Department of [[Dramaturgy]] in 1994 and the Department of [[Theatrical producer|Production]] in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asu.unsa.ba/index.php?option%3Dcom_content%26view%3Darticle%26id%3D105%26Itemid%3D160%26lang%3Dhr |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-08-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723210830/http://www.asu.unsa.ba/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=105&Itemid=160&lang=hr |archivedate=2012-07-23 |df= }}</ref>
An important segment of the academy's practice is its cooperation with the Open Stage "Obala", a prominent Sarajevo theater, where students present their works along with professional actors, directors and writers.
The need for the [[Academy for Performing Arts]] arose because, according to data from the year 1981, Bosnia and Herzegovina theaters had around 180 employees of which only 24 had the appropriate academic qualifications. Therefore, it was decided to establish Academy for Performing Arts in Sarajevo which was open to students from Bosnia and Herzegovina and other republics of [[former Yugoslavia]]. Academy of Performing Arts officially started working on December 2, 1981.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120729112449/http://www.asu.unsa.ba/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=57&Itemid=61&lang=hr/ ''Academy of Performing Arts in Sarajevo''(in Bosnian) [cited February 21, 2012]]</ref>
In 2010, it was announced that the [[Sarajevo Canton]] and the Cantonal Development Institute would be funding the construction of a 10 million [[Convertible Mark|KM]] building and center for the Academy of Performing Arts, primarily because working conditions for students and faculty alike have been subpar for the past decade. Construction on the new {{convert|4600|m²|0|abbr=on}} center began in mid-2010 in the [[Centar Municipality, Sarajevo|Centar Municipality]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sa-c.net/index.php/projects/projects-archive/item/419-akademija-scenskih-umjetnosti-sarajevo.html |title=Renovacija Akademije scenskih umjetnosti (Renovation of the Academy of Performing Arts) |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Sarajevo Construction News |accessdate=15 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120529093453/http://sa-c.net/index.php/projects/projects-archive/item/419-akademija-scenskih-umjetnosti-sarajevo.html |archivedate=29 May 2012 }}</ref>
==Notable alumni== Academy of Performing Arts in Sarajevo alumni include [[Academy Award|Oscar]], [[Berlin Film Festival]], and [[Cannes Film Festival]] award winners. Some of the distinguished alumni and staff include:<ref name=oster>{{cite book|url=http://www.asu.unsa.ba/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=86&Itemid=85|title=Tvorci cjeline : 20 godina Odsjeka za režiju Akademije scenskih umjetnosti u Sarajevu|last=|first=|publisher=Academy of Performing Arts in Sarajevo|pages=3–4|year=2009|isbn=978-9958-9409-2-7|accessdate=February 21, 2012}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
* [[Senad Bašić]] * [[Miraj Grbić]] * [[Benjamin Filipović]] * [[Elmir Jukić]] * [[Ademir Kenović]] * [[Emir Kusturica]], two-time [[Palme d'Or]] winner * [[Zana Marjanović]] * [[Snježana Martinović]] * [[Helena Minić]]<ref name="Globus">{{cite news |last1=Mikuličin |first1=Ivana |title=HELENA MINIĆ MATANIĆ 'Mnogi muškarci i u 21. stoljeću svoje supruge tretiraju kao ukras života' |url=https://www.jutarnji.hr/globus/Globus-kultura/helena-minic-matanic-mnogi-muskarci-i-u-21-stoljecu-svoje-supruge-tretiraju-kao-ukras-zivota/6809514/ |accessdate=2 October 2018 |work=Globus |date=4 December 2017}}</ref> * [[Haris Pašović]] * [[Danis Tanović]], [[Academy Award|Oscar]], [[Golden Globe]], [[Silver Bear]]-winning director and screenwriter * [[Pjer Žalica]] * [[Jasmila Žbanić]], [[Golden Bear]]-winning screenwriter and director
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=January 2011}}
The ADMS (advanced disaster management simulator) is an emergency and disaster management training [[Simulator|simulation]] system designed to train [[incident commander]]s, first responders, and incident command teams in a real-time, interactive [[virtual reality]](VR) environment.<ref name="multiple" /> ADMS was first introduced by Environmental Tectonics Corporation [http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/snapshot/snapshot.asp?ticker=ETCC:US (ETCC:US)] in 1992. The development of ADMS was in response to the crash of [[British Airtours Flight 28M]] at the Manchester airport in 1985, in which 55 people died. Following the accident research indicated that first responder training should include realistic scenarios. The first ADMS system was produced for the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|UK Ministry of Defence]], and delivered to [[RAF|Royal Air Force’s (RAF) Manston Facility]].<ref>{{cite journal | title = Virtual Preparation for ARFF Emerfgencies | journal = Industrial Fire Journal | date = 2008-10-01| id = | url = http://www.hemmingfire.com/news/fullstory.php/aid/433/Virtual_preparation_for_ARFF_emergencies.html | accessdate = 2010-09-17 | quote = ADMS was initially developed in response to the Manchester airport disaster in 1985 in which 55 people died. }}</ref> Since its inception, ADMS has evolved into a modular, expandable disaster simulation platform, with systems in use worldwide.
== History ==
===Virtual reality and emergency management training=== The successful use of virtual reality simulation in disaster management training initiatives is a popular area for research. It has been found that when trainees are able to participate, both verbally and physically in a training exercise, retention is 90%, in great contrast to a 10% retention rate of what they hear, and 50% retention rate of what they see and hear.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Improving Safety Instruction and Results: Five Principles of Sound Training |journal=American Society of Safety Engineers |date=December 2000 |first=Shawn J. |last=Adams |pages=40–41 |id= |url=http://assevirtualsymposium.pbworks.com/f/adams_1200.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2010-09-16 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Traditionally classroom lectures, tabletop exercises and live-training drills have been utilized for training. While these teaching methodologies are effective, virtual reality simulation seems to have bridged the gap between them. Virtual reality offers the opportunity to create an emergency situation that could not otherwise be experienced due to safety, cost and environmental factors.<ref name="multiple" /> From a safety standpoint, training in a synthetic environment allows the student to experiment while carrying out dangerous actions, and offers the ability to repeat the exercise until the trainee feels confident and prepared for real-life incidents.
== Technology == The ADMS relies on a [[physics engine]] and built in [[artificial intelligence]] to provide realistic, 3D emergency situations. The Disaster scenarios include [[algorithm]]s which take into account: type of threat, time of day, precipitation, wind, visibility, condition of casualties, terrain, and traffic and bystander behavior<ref>{{cite journal | title = Virtual Threat, Real Sweat | journal = American Society for Training and Development (ASTD) | year = 2007 | first = Jenni | last = Jarventaus| id = | url = http://www.astd.org/LC/2007/0507_jarventaus.htm | accessdate = 2010-09-15| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100814235126/http://www.astd.org/LC/2007/0507_jarventaus.htm| archivedate= 14 August 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> ADMS training exercises are unscripted and open-ended, requiring interactive decision making<ref name="multiple">{{Cite conference | first = Michael | last = Louka |author2= Claudio Balducelli | title = Virtual Reality Tools for Emergency Operation Support and Training | booktitle = Proceedings of TIEMS (The International Emergency Management Society) | date = 2001| id = | url =http://www2.hrp.no/vr/publications/tiems2001.pdf | accessdate = 2010-09-15}}</ref> and participation from the users to affect the outcome of the training exercise. The development, escalation, or resolution of the situation is determined by the trainees' decisions and the use of intelligent resources they command.
ADMS is a networked framework and a family of applications which may be run on a single station or as a multi-user system with several networked stations giving independent access to several viewpoints and control interfaces within the same environment and scenario. ADMS projects its simulations using panoramic [[high-definition multimedia interface]], visual displays and directional sound. The simulation engine includes key models including: artificial intelligence, physics, logic, and messaging and applications comprising a visual engine, sound engine, messaging daemon and [[graphical user interface]].
=== Environments === ADMS environments are developed in either geo-typical or geo-specific environments. Geo-specific environments are created using exact [[3D modeling]] of the specified location, and can include buildings, streets, vehicles, terrain and people, specific airports or schools, or entire cities.
== Products and applications == * '''ADMS-COMMAND''' Designed for training incident commanders in a diverse range of emergency scenarios, ranging from car accidents to low-frequency, high casualty situations, either in single or multi-agency operations. Trainees make decisions and give verbal commands, enabling the real-time action of the simulator.<ref name="virtuallyreal">{{cite journal | title = Virtually Real | journal = EMS Magazine | date = 2009-08-01 | first = John | last = Erich| id = | url = http://www.emsresponder.com/print/EMS-Product-News/Virtually-Real/2$8388 | accessdate = 2010-09-17}}</ref> The system can be expanded to include additional simulation elements, including vehicle controls and cabs, and 180 degree immersive visual displays.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://medtechiq.ning.com/video/2140535:Video:5427 | title = BioDefense:ADMS:Advanced Disaster Management Simulator | accessdate = 2010-09-17 | last = Clyburn | first = Conrad | date = 2008-10-30 | work = MedTech IQ | publisher = Clymer Group}}</ref> * '''ADMS-DRIVE''' Designed to train, assess and recertify drivers in safe and effective driving procedures. It is also utilized as a training platform to train emergency responders to drive under stressful situations, and by airport snow removal teams to train in snow removal operations during winter conditions. ADMS-DRIVE immerses the user in a realistic, virtual environment in which dynamic elements such as traffic, signal lights, people and weather create a realistic and challenging representation of the situation.<ref name="virtuallyreal" /> * '''ADMS-ARFF''' Designed as an [[aircraft rescue and firefighting]] vehicle simulator which focuses on correct [[turret]] operation, driving and communication, vehicle positioning, firefighting with turrets and Command and Control. The trainee uses controls and joysticks to maneuver the vehicle in an airport environment and deals with airplane disaster.<ref name="virtuallyreal" /> * '''ADMS-HRET''' HRET (High-reach extendable turret) is intended to be a training aid for operators to become familiar with, and enhance the skills necessary for actual hands on operation of the Rosenbauer HRET. HRET is a portable desktop system that comes with a console that includes a real HRET-joystick and relevant switches. Trainees can drive to the scene, train various external and internal fire scenarios, and penetrate the aircraft by using the piercing device.<ref name="lance" /> * '''ADMS-BART''' The behavioral assessment research tool (BART) was developed initially for the Netherlands Institute for Safety, Research Department. BART focuses on human behavior and the effect it has in a real-life incident.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Exit choice, (pre-)movement time and (pre-) evacuation behavior in hotel fire evacuation – Behavioral analysis and validation of the use of serious gaming in experimental research | journal = Procedia Engineering | year = 2010 | first = Margrethe | last = Kobes |author2=Ira Helsloot|author3=Burke de Vries|author4=Jos Post | volume = 3 | pages = 37–51| doi = 10.1016/j.proeng.2010.07.006 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=MImg&_imagekey=B9869-50TXY0Y-5-1&_cdi=59121&_user=10&_pii=S1877705810004753&_origin=search&_coverDate=12%2F31%2F2010&_sk=999969999&view=c&wchp=dGLzVlb-zSkzV&md5=b82de0602302c37c2f3b336ecd2e0bfa&ie=/sdarticle.pdf | accessdate = 2010-09-15 | quote = The relative-validation analysis revealed that the use of ADMS-BART can be considered valid as a research tool for research on wayfinding performance.}}</ref> ADMS-BART creates an environment where virtual human subjects act as they would in a live situation. This system made it possible to use virtual reality for studying virtual behaviors in fires, allowing for changes in the live environment to mitigate the damages in the event of a live incident. * '''ADMS-US''' Is a standardized simulation system, programmed with ten (10) geo-typical situation environments which resemble Anytown USA. ADMS-US is a portable, laptop based simulator which is utilized for either individual or multi-agency training who do not require geo-specific capabilities.
== Compliance == On January 27, 2009, the U.S. Army Program Executive Office for Simulation, Training and Instrumentation (PEO STRI) awarded ETC STOC II eligibility for the ADMS.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bop.peostri.army.mil/sites/bop/Contract%20Vehicles/STOCII_DOCS/STOCIIAwardeeswPOCandEMAIL-LotI.pdf |title=STOC II List of Awardees |accessdate=2010-09-17 |date=2010-05-07 |format=PDF |publisher=U.S. Army PEO STRI – Business Opportunities Portal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722182252/https://bop.peostri.army.mil/sites/bop/Contract%20Vehicles/STOCII_DOCS/STOCIIAwardeeswPOCandEMAIL-LotI.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-22 }}</ref> STOC II is an ID/IQ (Indefinite Delivery/Indefinite Quantity) contract vehicle with a ceiling of $17.5 billion over a period of 10 years. All branches of the military are eligible to utilize STOC II to quickly obtain simulation and training solutions from a panel of pre-qualified companies. The purpose of this contract vehicle was to provide an efficient method for the U.S. military and its coalition service members to acquire what they need.
Additionally, ADMS was designed to be NIMS compliant. The [[National Incident Management System]] has developed a unified approach to allow governmental agencies to work in unison with the private sector with the common goal of preparing for, preventing, responding to, recovering from, and mitigating the effects of incidents of any cause, size, location, or complexity.
== Users == * [[New York City Office of Emergency Management]] * Rochester Fire Department / Public Safety Training Facility (PSTF) - Rochester, NY * [[Minneapolis-Saint Paul International Airport|Minneapolis – St. Paul International Airport]]<ref>{{cite journal | title = Taking the Oops Out of Vehicle Ops | journal = Air Transport World | date = 2005-07-01 | first = John | last = Croft| id = | url = http://atwonline.com/airports-routes/article/taking-oops-out-vehicle-ops-0309 | accessdate = 2010-09-16}}</ref> * Florida State Fire College * Netherlands Institute for Safety (NIFV) * South Korea National Fire Service Academy (SFNFSA) * Pennsylvania Southeast Region Counter Terrorism Task Force * Aurora Community College * Butler County Community College * Noblesville Fire Department * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101024143754/http://firstresponders.pcsb.org/ Pinellas Park High School] * [[Rosenbauer]]<ref name="lance">{{cite journal | title = Shoot the Lance Safely | journal = Industrial Fire Journal | date = 2009-06-10| id = | url = http://www.hemmingfire.com/news/fullstory.php/aid/544/Shoot_the_lance_safely.html | accessdate = 2010-09-16}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.etcusa.com Environmental Tectonics Corporation's Website] *[http://www.TrainingForDisasterManagement.com Environmental Tectonics Corporation, Simulation Division Website] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SkmAH1qayhU ADMS on WPIX News Channel 11, New York]
[[Category:Incident management]] [[Category:Disaster preparedness]] [[Category:Firefighter training]] [[Category:Simulation]] [[Category:Virtual reality]] [[Category:Emergency management software]]

The '''Architect Registration Examination''' ('''ARE''') is the professional [[licensure]] examination adopted by the 50 states of the [[United States]], the District of Columbia, and three U.S. territories (Guam, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands). The exam is also accepted by 11 provincial and territorial architectural associations for architectural registration in Canada. The ARE assesses candidates on the knowledge, skills, and abilities required for provided services in the practice of [[architecture]].
The ARE is developed and maintained by the [[National Council of Architectural Registration Boards]] (NCARB). NCARB currently offers two versions of the computer-based exam, ARE 4.0, which will retire on June 30, 2018, and ARE 5.0. Both versions are administered in Prometric test centers across the United States and Canada, as well as London, Abu Dhabi, and Hong Kong.
==History== The earliest examinations were written and scored by each individual state board. Practicing architects, educators, and specialists in other disciplines were organized to prepare and score these tests. Since each state prepared its own test specifications, test questions, and passing standard, there was little uniformity among the boards on examination, no effective reciprocity system, and no equal protection for the public across the nation.
As NCARB grew, it organized delegates from its Member Boards into working groups during its Annual Meetings to address the problem of exam uniformity. Their efforts eventually led to agreement on a syllabus of written examination subjects. Subsequently, the length of each test and the dates of administration were agreed on, and this concurrence served to achieve the goal of greater consistency in examination questions and scoring.
By the late 1950s, [[standardized testing]] had made impressive progress. The NCARB examination committees studied the latest developments and converted sections of the syllabus to a multiple-choice format by the mid-1960s and made them available to all of NCARB Member Boards.<ref>[http://www.ncarb.org/Publications/~/media/Files/PDF/Special-Paper/history.pdf History of NCARB]</ref>
In 1979, NCARB conducted an extensive "task analysis and validation study" that led to the development of the forerunner of today's ARE. At that time, candidates were required to take all nine divisions over a four-day period and the exam was only offered once a year in major cities across the United States.
In the late 1980s, as the practice of architecture moved into the computer age, NCARB began to develop a computer-based exam. After a decade of research and development, the last paper-and-pencil test was issued in 1996, and the computer-based exam rolled out in 1997.
NCARB conducted comprehensive Practice Analysis studies in 2001, 2007, and 2012 that led to improvements of the ARE. These improvements have since been rolled out in ARE 3.0, ARE 3.1, ARE 4.0, and ARE 5.0, which launched November 1, 2016. ARE 4.0 will retire on June 30, 2018. [2]
==Eligibility== Before an ARE division can be scheduled, candidates must be approved to test and receive eligibilities from their state board. The majority of states participate in the Direct Eligibility Program, which enables NCARB to manage a candidate’s eligibilities. Most states require completion of a professional degree from the [[National Architectural Accrediting Board]] (NAAB) ([[Bachelor of Architecture|B.Arch]] or [[Master of Architecture|M.Arch]]), and some require candidates to record professional experience before testing. [https://www.ncarb.org/get-licensed/licensing-requirements-tool A full list of requirements for each state is available on the NCARB website.]
==Process== In order to take the ARE, candidates must meet the requirements of the registration board he or she plans to receive an initial license from, establish an NCARB Record, and receive an Authorization to Test (ATT).<ref>[http://www.ncarb.org/ARE/Getting-Started-With-the-ARE.aspx Getting Started With the ARE]</ref>
Each division of the ARE is taken separately at a Prometric test center. Divisions are scored by Prometric as either pass or fail and then sent to the jurisdiction that grants the candidate the authorization to test, which then notifies the candidate. A pass score is valid for five years, sometime less depending on the jurisdiction's rules. Prior to October 2014, a candidate who failed a division would not be eligible to retake that division for six months, NCARB shortened that time to 60 days for all tests taken since August.
Under the requirements of NCARB's Rolling Clock, a candidate must pass all divisions of the ARE within five years. Some jurisdictions require the exam be completed in less time.<ref>[http://www.ncarb.org/ARE/Taking-the-ARE/Rolling-Clock.aspx NCARB Rolling Clock]</ref>
==Difficulty==
The ARE assesses candidates’ knowledge, skills, and ability to practice architecture independently. It focuses on those services that most affect the health, safety, and welfare of the public. Because of this, the exams are rigorous and require demonstration of competency in each of the testing areas.
==Test structure==
NCARB currently offers one version of the exam: ARE 5.0.
=== ARE 3.0 === The ARE 3.0 was introduced in 1998. Use was discontinued in 2003. Utilized a similar structure to 4.0. Graphic vignettes and multiple choice questions were on separate tests.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://davidthaddeus.com/are-facts/|title=ARE Facts|website=David Thaddeus|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-20}}</ref>
=== ARE 3.1 === The ARR 3.1 was introduced in 2003. Use was discontinued in 2009.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://davidthaddeus.com/are-facts/|title=ARE Facts|website=David Thaddeus|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-20}}</ref>
* Pre-Design (105 MC questions) * General Structures (85 MC questions) * Lateral Forces (75 MC questions) * Mechanical and Electrical Systems (105 MC questions) * Building Design/Materials and Methods (105 MC questions) * Construction Documents & Services (115 MC questions) * Site Planning (Site zoning, site Grading, and Site Design vignettes) * Building Planning (Interior layout and schematic design vignettes) * Building Technology (Building section, structural layout, accessibility/ramp, mechanical and electrical plan, stair design and roof plan vignettes)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-_RqE4t2I8Vc/TehjMG21VCI/AAAAAAAACK8/fWhosGz5x40/s1600/transition+chart.jpg|title=ARE Transition Chart|last=Architectoid|first=|date=|website=NCARB|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
===ARE 4.0===
The ARE 4.0 was introduced in July 2008 and consists of seven divisions:[5] *Programming, Planning & Practice (85 multiple choice and fill-in questions, and one site zoning vignette) *Site Planning & Design (65 multiple choice and fill-in questions, and two vignettes: site grading and site planning) *Building Design & Construction Systems (85 multiple choice and fill-in questions, and three vignettes in accessibility, roof plan and stair design) *Schematic Design (two vignettes in building layout and interior layout) *Structural Systems (125 multiple choice and fill-in questions, and one structural layout vignette) *Building Systems (95 multiple choice and fill-in questions, and one mechanical & electrical plan vignette) *Construction Documentation & Services (100 multiple choice and fill-in questions, and one building section vignette) *ARE 4.0 will be available through June 30, 2018.
===ARE 5.0===
ARE 5.0 was introduced in November 2016 and consists of six divisions. These divisions include multiple-choice questions, check-all-that-apply, fill-in-the-blank, hotspot, drag-and-place, and case study questions. *Practice Management (80 items) *Project Management (95 items) *Programming & Analysis (95 items) *Project Planning & Design (120 items) *Project Development & Documentation (120 items) *Construction & Evaluation (95 items)
==Exam confidentiality==
All NCARB tests are held in strict security and confidence and are protected by [[United States copyright law|U.S. copyright laws]]. Before beginning the test, candidates are required to accept NCARB's Confidentiality Agreement, which prohibits any disclosure of exam content.
Candidates found to have violated the Confidentiality Agreement are referred to NCARB's Committee on Professional Conduct. The Committee reviews each case and then recommends a disciplinary action. The cases are then forwarded to the NCARB Board of Directors for review and final disciplinary action. All disciplinary actions taken by the Board of Directors are final and become a part of each individual's permanent NCARB Record. Individual candidates may also be subject to additional disciplinary measures from their state board.
When exam content is disclosed, NCARB works with the test consultant, Prometric, to determine the impact on the exam. If NCARB finds that it is necessary to remove (or turn off) content, the ability to continuously deliver the ARE is seriously jeopardized.<ref>[http://www.ncarb.org/ARE/Taking-the-ARE/Exam-Security.aspx Exam Security]</ref>
==Resources==
===ARE 4.0=== All candidates preparing to take ARE 4.0 should download the [https://www.ncarb.org/Publications/List.aspx?t=Guidelines ARE 4.0 Guidelines]. This free publication contains an overview of the ARE 4.0 divisions, as well as information about the practice programs, the rolling clock, and maintaining exam eligibility. Additionally, NCARB offers free exam guides and practice programs for each of the seven divisions, available on its website.
===ARE 5.0=== All candidates preparing to take ARE 5.0 should download the [https://www.ncarb.org/pass-are/are5/prepare ARE 5.0 Guidelines]. This free publication contains an overview of the ARE 5.0 divisions. The ARE 5.0 Handbook, a free demo exam, short videos about the new question types, and a list of references for further study can be found at [https://www.ncarb.org/press/what-you-need-know-about-are-50 NCARB.org].
==See also== * [[Examination for Architects in Canada]] * [[Architectural Experience Program (AXP)]] * [[National Council of Architectural Registration Boards]] (NCARB)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://ncarb.org NCARB] ** [http://www.ncarb.org/ARE.aspx ARE Homepage] ** [http://www.ncarb.org/ARE/ARE-Overview/ARE-History.aspx ARE History] ** [http://www.ncarb.org/ARE/ARE-Pass-Rates.aspx ARE Pass Rates] ** [http://www.ncarb.org/ARE/Preparing-for-the-ARE.aspx Preparing for the ARE] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080927212707/http://www.cexac.ca/en/exac.php Examination for Architects in Canada website]
[[Category:Professional certification in architecture]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Beautiful Boy | image = Beautiful Boy (2010 film).jpg | director = [[Shawn Ku]] | producer = Lee Clay
Eric Gozlan | writer = Michael Armbruster
Shawn Ku | starring = [[Michael Sheen]]
[[Maria Bello]]
[[Alan Tudyk]]
[[Moon Bloodgood]]
[[Kyle Gallner]] | music = [[Trevor Morris (musician)|Trevor Morris]] | cinematography = [[Michael Fimognari]] | editing = Chad Galster | distributor = [[Anchor Bay Entertainment]] | released = {{Film date|2010|9||[[San Sebastián International Film Festival|San Sebastián]]|2011|6|3|United States}} | runtime = | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Beautiful Boy''''' is a 2010 drama film starring [[Michael Sheen]] and [[Maria Bello]]. ==Plot== The film opens up with home videos of a husband and wife at the beach with their young son. A young man reads a short story about a boy and girl; saying that they didn't know it, but their lives would one day irrevocably change. Bill ([[Michael Sheen]]) and Kate ([[Maria Bello]]) are a married couple who are tightly wound and devoted to their work. Bill is a businessman, and Kate proofreads books for a living. The only thing keeping them together is their eighteen-year-old son Sam ([[Kyle Gallner]]), who is having trouble adjusting to college. One morning, it's reported on the news that there has been a [[school shooting|shooting spree]] at Sam's school. They are then visited by the police who inform them that Sam is not only dead, but that he was the gunman. Kate refuses to believe that their son would do something so horrible, and spends the night tidying up Sam's room as if nothing has happened. As the news media descends upon the couple, Bill and Kate decide to stay with Kate's brother Eric ([[Alan Tudyk]]) and his wife Trish ([[Moon Bloodgood]]). The next morning, Eric and Trish's son Dylan (Cody Wai-Ho Lee) turns on the television to see a video made by Sam about the impending massacre. Bill then decides to issue a public statement, saying that they are both deeply sorry over what has happened, and ask for their privacy as they endeavor to get their lives back on track. They have a small funeral with only family present. Trish soon becomes agitated at Kate's nit-picking, and her attempts to mother Dylan, but Eric says that she has to be sensitive to their situation since Sam was her only child. They eventually leave, saying they are going to visit a friend, but check into a motel instead. The manager ([[Meat Loaf]]) not knowing who they are, makes a comment about Sam and his "monster family". Bill goes back to the house where he finds a teenage boy in Sam's room. They have a short scuffle where Bill cuts his hand, and the boy calls him a "psycho". He returns to the motel with their laptop, and finds a video from Sam. He and Kate view it together; Sam only says "mom and dad , I'm sorry, please don't hate me". Bill and Kate get into an argument about what could have caused Sam to kill all those innocent people. Bill lashes out at Kate for always critiquing every decision that Sam made, but she says that he was never there for them because he was always so busy working. Bill ends up saying that he wishes that Sam was never born, and Kate leaves. She goes back to their house for the first time since the shooting, and looks through Sam's room. Bill meets with his boss Harry ([[Bruce French (actor)|Bruce French]]), who agrees that he can return to work next week. While grocery shopping, Kate runs into her young co-worker Cooper ([[Austin Nichols]]). They go back to the house, and she catches him looking through Sam's short stories. He says that he is writing a piece about the shooting, but that he wanted to portray Sam in a more human light by learning more about him. Bill finally returns to work, but feels alienated by the rest of the staff. Harry tells Bill to take more time off to see a therapist, so he quits. Bill later visits the cemetery to find Sam's gravestone vandalized, with the word ''killer'' written on it. He breaks down both physically and emotionally as he tries to scrub the word off with his bandaged hand. Kate reads all of Sam's stories, and goes to Sam's gravestone as well. She gets a call from the motel manager about Bill, and finds him curled up in their old room. Kate embraces the emotionally distraught Bill, and takes him home. Sam's voice is heard again as he ends his short story about the boy and girl. He says that no matter what they do, their lives will never be the same. ==Cast== *[[Michael Sheen]] as Bill Carroll *[[Maria Bello]] as Kate Carroll *[[Alan Tudyk]] as Eric *[[Moon Bloodgood]] as Trish *[[Kyle Gallner]] as Sam Carroll *[[Meat Loaf]] as the motel manager ==Production== Filming took place in [[Los Angeles]] and [[Santa Clarita, California|Santa Clarita]], [[California]]. ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.beautifulboythemovie.com/}} * {{IMDb title|1533013|Beautiful Boy}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|Beautiful_Boy|Beautiful Boy}} [[Category:2010 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:Films about school violence]] [[Category:Films shot in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Films shot in California]]

{{primary sources|date=May 2008}}
The [[Ministry of Education Culture and Science of Mongolia]], [[Ministry of Finance of Mongolia]], New World Foundation of Mongolia and Young Leader Club together with the [[Mongolian National Broadcaster|Mongolian National Television]] annually select the Best Student of the certain year. To be nominated, the student has to be pursuing undergraduate studies in [[Mongolia]]. The award ceremony has been organized for the last decade. It is the most prestigious award that can be given to a student pursuing an undergraduate degree in Mongolia. Its recipients are awarded a full scholarship to study in a prestigious university anywhere in the world. The Ministry of Education covers the full financial support. The award ceremony has always been broadcast on Mongolian National Television (Mongolian National Broadcaster- MNB).
==External links== * [http://www.mof.gov.mn/ MOF] in Mongolian * [http://www.mnb.mn/ MNB] in Mongolian
[[Category:Student awards]] [[Category:Education in Mongolia]]

{{Infobox organization |name = Bharti Foundation |type = [[Private foundation|Non-government private foundation]] |logo = Bharti logo.jpg |image = Satyabharti.jpg |caption = Satya Bharti School run by Bharti Foundation |founded_date = 2000 |founder = [[Sunil Mittal]] |location = Airtel Center, [[Gurgaon]] |origins = |key_people = [[Sunil Mittal]] (Chairman), [[Anil Kumar]] (founding board member) |area_served = [[India]] |product = |mission = To help underprivileged children and young people of our country realize their potential |focus = To improve the accessibility and quality of education at school level across rural India |method = [[Public-private partnership]] |revenue = |endowment = |num_volunteers = |num_employees = |num_members = |subsid = |owner = [[Bharti Enterprises]] |Non-profit_slogan = |homepage = [http://www.bhartifoundation.org bhartifoundation.org] |dissolved = |footnotes = }} '''Bharti Foundation''' is the philanthropic arm of [[Bharti Enterprises]], an [[India]]n business [[Conglomerate (company)|conglomerate]] based in [[New Delhi]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.bhartifoundation.org/wps/wcm/connect/bhartifoundation/BhartiFoundation/Home | work=Bharti Foundation | title=About Us | accessdate=14 March 2012}}</ref> It conducts free programs in both primary and [[higher education]] for the underprivileged children, with a particular focus on girls. The Satya Bharti School Program, started in 2006, is the flagship program of Bharti Foundation.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.ngoportal.org/ngo-database-1869-Bharti+Foundation.html | work=NGO Portal | title=Bharti Foundation | accessdate=14 March 2012}}</ref>
The foundation, based in [[Gurgaon]], India, is governed by 16 board members, including [[Sunil Mittal]] as its chairman and Rakesh Mittal as its co-chairman.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.bhartifoundation.org/wps/wcm/connect/bhartifoundation/BhartiFoundation/Home/About+Us/Our%20Boards/PG_OurBoards#governing_board| title=Governing Board | accessdate=14 March 2012}}</ref> The foundation has been recognized by many societies and award committees for its [[corporate social responsibility]] programs. Some of them include the Global CSR Award, Asian CSR Award, The Indian Education Award 2011, and World Education Award 2011.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.bhartifoundation.org/wps/wcm/connect/bhartifoundation/BhartiFoundation/Home/About+Us/AwardsRecognitions/PG_AwardsandRecognitions| title=Awards & Recognitions | accessdate=14 March 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Educational charities]]

'''Christine Johnson Smith''' (September 8, 1911 – June 9, 2010<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.operanews.com/Opera_News_Magazine/2010/9/Departments/Obituaries.html|title=Obituaries: Christine Johnson|work=[[Opera News]]|date=September 2010|volume=75|number=3}}</ref>), usually credited as '''Christine Johnson''', was an American [[contralto]] [[opera singer]] and actress who sang at the [[Metropolitan Opera]] and other [[opera houses]]. She is best known, however, for creating the role of Nettie Fowler in the original [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production of ''[[Carousel (musical)|Carousel]]''.
==Life and career== Johnson was born in [[Hopkinsville, Kentucky]] and moved to [[Owensboro, Kentucky]] after her freshman year of high school, graduating from [[Owensboro High School]] in 1929.<ref>[http://www.owensboro.kyschools.us/pressreleases/OHS%20Hall%20of%20Achievement%202001%20Inductees.htm Owensboro High School 2002 Hall of Achievement]</ref> She showed early promise, starring in school plays and singing in churches.<ref name=nomination>1998 Kentucky Governor's Awards in the Arts nomination, on file in the Kentucky governor's office.</ref> After high school, she studied voice at the Nashville Conservatory of Music and sang for radio station [[WSM (AM)|WSM]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].
Johnson moved to [[New York City]] in 1937 and began to work with NBC's [[Radio City Music Hall]] and [[Lyn Murray]] and the [[Columbia Symphony Orchestra]] at CBS, sometimes touring in concerts in North America. She studied voice and operatic repertoire in New York with Ernst Knoth and Sidney Dietch. In 1941, she sang Dorabella in ''[[Così fan tutte]]'', opening the [[Tanglewood]] opera house at [[Lenox, Massachusetts]].<ref>A 1938 Broadway role listed in the IBDB is erroneous.</ref>
In 1942, she received good notices for the role of Mrs. Page in ''[[The Merry Wives of Windsor (opera)|The Merry Wives of Windsor]]''. Other roles followed for her, with the New Opera Company of New York under [[Emil Cooper]], at [[San Francisco Opera]] and elsewhere, in ''[[Macbeth (opera)|Macbeth]]'', ''[[The Fair at Sorochyntsi]]'', ''[[The Queen of Spades (opera)|The Queen of Spades]]'', ''[[Cavalleria rusticana]]'', ''[[Carmen]]'', ''[[La forza del destino]]'', ''[[The Girl of the Golden West]]'', the title role in ''[[Roberta]]'', Azucena in ''[[Il trovatore]]'' and Maddalena in ''[[Rigoletto]]''.<ref name=KS>[http://www.downtownlex.com/kentucky_stars_05.asp Kentucky Stars profile of Christine Johnson Smith] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820132948/http://www.downtownlex.com/kentucky_stars_05.asp |date=August 20, 2008 }}</ref> During this period, she also sang at New York's [[The Town Hall|Town Hall]].<ref name=nomination/>
In 1943, Johnson won the [[Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air]] which led to her becoming the youngest person ever to sing the role of Erda in [[Richard Wagner]]'s ''[[Das Rheingold]]'' at that opera house.<ref>[http://66.187.153.86/archives/scripts/cgiip.exe/WService=BibSpeed/gisrch2k.r?Term=Johnson,%20Christine%20%5BMezzo%20Soprano%5D&limit=2500&vsrchtype=no&xBranch=ALL&xmtype=&Start=&End=&theterm=Johnson,%20Ch%72is%74in%65%20%5BM%65zzo%20Sop%72ano%5D&srt=&x=0&xHome=&xHomePath= List of performances by Johnson at the Metropolitan Opera]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> She appeared on CBS radio's ''The Squibb Show'' twice in 1944. There she sang "It's A Lovely Day" and "My Heart's in the Highlands" with Lyn Murray and His Orchestra.<ref>[http://www.radiogoldindex.com/cgi-local/p3.cgi?ArtistName=Johnson,+Christine&ArtistNumber=06667 Johnson's appearances on ''The Squibb Show'']{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In 1945, Johnson created the role of Nettie Fowler in ''[[Carousel (musical)|Carousel]]''. [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]] wrote "[[You'll Never Walk Alone (song)|You'll Never Walk Alone]]", which has become a standard, and "June is Busting Out All Over" especially for her.<ref name=KS/> {{Dead link|date=January 2011}} She also sang the role on the show's [[Cast recording|original cast album]]. Johnson stayed with the show for hundreds of performances and then toured and studied in Italy for a time.<ref name=nomination/> She rejoined ''Carousel'' during the national tour and continued as Nettie through its Broadway revival in 1949.<ref name=KS/>
After ''Carousel'' closed, Johnson moved back to Owensboro, where she married surgeon Robert Smith in 1950 and raised two daughters, Robin and Nancy. She taught voice for many years,<ref name=KS/> and one of her pupils was [[Florence Henderson]].<ref>[http://www.laweekly.com/columns/a-considerable-town/mrs-brady-sings-the-blues/13512/ Johnson and Florence Henderson]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> She also served on local arts committees and participated in some local productions. Johnson's husband died in 1959, and she later worked for Texas Gas Transmission Corporation until her retirement.<ref name=nomination/>
Johnson died on June 9, 2010 at the age of 98, and was buried at [[Rosehill Elmwood Cemetery]].
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080820132948/http://www.downtownlex.com/kentucky_stars_05.asp Profile of Christine Johnson Smith]
==External links== *{{IBDB name}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927222115/http://www.rnh.com/williamson/?page=song&song_id=1530 Williamson Music] *[http://www.cduniverse.com/search/xx/music/pid/1142664/a/Carousel.htm ''Carousel'' CD]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
'''Concho Indian Boarding School''' (also known as the '''Cheyenne-Arapaho Boarding School at Concho''' or '''Concho Indian School''' and home to the '''Concho Demonstration School''') was a [[American Indian boarding schools|boarding school]] for members of the [[Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes]] and later opened to other Native American students. It existed from 1909 to 1983. It was located in central Oklahoma, approximately 1 mile south of [[Concho, Oklahoma]] and 4 miles north of [[El Reno, Oklahoma]].<ref name="Dias (1933)">{{cite journal|last1=Dias|first1=William T.|title=Historical Sketch of Cheyenne-Arapaho School and Agency|journal=Oklahoma Indian School Magazine|date=1933|volume= 2|issue= 2|pages=5–6|url=http://digitalprairie.ok.gov/cdm/ref/collection/culture/id/2311|accessdate=3 February 2015|publisher=Chilocco Indian Boarding School|location=Chilocco, Oklahoma}}</ref> The name of the town and school is the Spanish word for "shell" and was named for the Indian agent, Charles E. Shell.<ref name="Shirk (1987)">{{cite book|last1=Shirk|first1=George H.|title=Oklahoma place names|date=1987|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|location=Norman, OK|isbn=0-8061-2028-2|page=57|edition=2d ed., rev. and enl.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KpAmsIFdutAC&lpg}}</ref>
==Curriculum== Concho was developed to provide a means of integrating and assimilating American Indian children into mainstream society. It, like other federal boarding schools, was run on a strict military model.<ref name="Anthes (2006)">{{cite book|last1=Anthes|first1=Bill|title=Native moderns: American Indian painting, 1940-1960|date=2006|publisher=Duke University Press|location=Durham|isbn=978-0822338666|page=149|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WI7gA-DNYegC&lpg}}</ref> Students were wakened at 5 a.m., performed military drills and formations, ate breakfast and were in class by 6:00 each morning.<ref name="Fowler (2010)">{{cite book|last1=Fowler|first1=Loretta|title=Wives and husbands : gender and age in Southern Arapaho history|date=2010|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|location=Norman|isbn=978-0-8061-4116-9|pages=202–204|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Iyjp09G3fp4C&lpg|accessdate=2 February 2015}}</ref> Academics, including reading, writing, and arithmetic,<ref name="Lyman (2013)">{{cite journal|last1=Lyman|first1=Rebecka|title=Life’s Journeys Simple woman, simple life|journal=Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribal Tribune|date=January 1, 2013|volume=8|issue=5|page=1|url=http://www.c-a-tribes.org/Websites/michaelwood/images/Newspapers/2013/Jan_1_2013.pdf|accessdate=2 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130213091507/http://www.c-a-tribes.org/Websites/michaelwood/images/Newspapers/2013/Jan_1_2013.pdf|archivedate=13 February 2013|df=}}</ref> were studied for half the day and the remainder of the day consisted of labor.<ref name="Fowler (2010)" />
Trades and farming were taught to boys<ref name="Anthes (2006)" /> and girls were taught domestic labor<ref name="Lyman (2013)" /> and nursing. A large experimental farm was maintained, where the children were instructed in conservation<ref name="WPA 1941">{{cite book|last1=Federal Writers Project of the WPA|title=Oklahoma: A Guide to the Sooner State|date=1941|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|pages=372–373|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HvlFlr7fS0QC&lpg|accessdate=30 January 2015}}</ref> and planting techniques. Boys milked cows and girls helped prepare all of the meals and sewed clothing.<ref name="Fowler (2010)" /> Discipline was strict and infractions, like speaking in their native language rather than English, were punished by things like breaking large rocks into smaller rocks<ref name="Anthes (2006)" /> or sawing wood.<ref name="Fowler (2010)" /> Each infraction required punishment of one hour of labor.<ref name="Anthes (2006)" />
Initially, the school offered education to the 6th grade and students would have to transfer to [[Carlisle Indian Industrial School|Carlisle]], [[Chilocco Indian Agricultural School|Chilocco]] or [[Haskell Institute]] for secondary education. By around the 1920s, the school curriculum mirrored public education being offered throughout the country and included sports, music, art, and a full course of educational subjects.<ref name="Fowler (2010)" /> By the time the school closed in the early 1980s, it offered instruction for grades one - eight and was predominantly attended by orphans and students who had difficult home environments.<ref name="Senate (1982)">{{cite web|title=Closing of Off-Reservation Boarding Schools. Hearing before the Select Committee on Indian Affairs|url=https://archive.org/stream/ERIC_ED226882/ERIC_ED226882_djvu.txt|publisher=United States Senate|accessdate=2 February 2015|date=February 24, 1982}}</ref>
==History== The first school was opened at the [[Darlington Agency]] on the Cheyenne-Arapaho Reservation in 1871 by the Hicksite (Liberal) Friends and Orthodox [[Quakers]] and was called the Cheyenne-Arapaho Boarding School.<ref name="McKellips (1992)">{{cite journal|last1=McKellips|first1=Karen K|title=Educational Practices in Two Nineteenth Century American Indian Mission Schools|journal=Journal of American Indian Education|date=October 1992|volume= 32| issue = 1|accessdate=}}</ref> In 1872, the facility was built with federal funds,<ref name=Everett>{{cite web|last1=Everett |first1=Dianna |title=SEGER, JOHN HOMER (1846-1928) |url=http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/S/SE005.html |website=Oklahoma State University |publisher=Oklahoma Historical Society |accessdate=30 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121119165141/http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/S/SE005.html |archivedate=19 November 2012 |df= }}</ref> but run by the [[Quakers]]. Few Cheyenne children attended the school and as a means to entice them, a partition was erected to divide the classroom into separate areas for the Arapaho and Cheyenne students.<ref name="McKellips (1992)" /> In 1879 the facility was renamed the Arapaho Manual Labor and Boarding School and a new facility was built for the Cheyenne students located at Caddo Springs, which was called the Cheyenne Manual Labor and Boarding School.<ref name=Everett /> Within 5 years, it was reported that the children at the agency schools were responsible for raising 211 cattle and hogs and cultivating 130 acres of land.<ref name="Steere (2009)">{{cite book|last1=Steere|first1=Bobby F.|title=The trace of the Southern Arapaho|date=2009|publisher=iUniverse, Inc.|location=Bloomington, Ind.|isbn=978-1-4401-0402-2|page=36|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GxVQaUYBlKcC&lpg|accessdate=2 February 2015}}</ref>
In 1881, a new school, called the Darlington Mission School was built and run by the General Conference [[Mennonite]]s but a fire which occurred on 19 February 1882 destroyed the building, taking the life of the missionary's infant son and three Indian children. Federal funds and donations from the Mennonite Mission Board were secured to rebuild the mission school by December, 1882.<ref name="Thiesen (2006)">{{cite journal|last1=Thiesen|first1=Barbara A|title=Every Beginning Is Hard: Darlington Mennonite Mission, 1880-1902|journal=Mennonite Life|date=June 2006|volume= 61| issue = 2|url=http://ml.bethelks.edu/issue/vol-61-no-2/article/every-beginning-is-hard-darlington-mennonite-missi/ |accessdate=30 January 2015}}</ref> The Mennonites had the same problems as the [[Quakers]] had had in trying educating the two tribes together, and opened a fourth school in 1882<ref name="McKellips (1992)" /> called Cantonment. By 1884, the agent reported that attendance in the four schools represented 66 students at the Arapaho boarding school, 22 students at Cantonment, 71 students at the Cheyenne boarding school and 28 students at Darlington.<ref name="Thiesen (2006)" />
After 1891 federal policy shifted and began to require more standardization, attendance quotas and less use of federal funds for church "contracted" institutions.<ref name="Thiesen (2006)" /> By the mid 1890s only about half of the school-age children on the Cheyenne-Arapaho Reservation were attending school. An experiment with enrolling Indian children in the public school system and offsetting the costs to the schools was attempted in 1896-1897, but was discontinued.<ref name="Berthrong (1992)">{{cite book|last1=Berthrong|first1=Donald J.|title=The Cheyenne and Arapaho ordeal : reservation and agency life in the Indian territory, 1875-1907|date=1992|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|location=Norman|isbn=0-8061-2416-4|edition=New|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3AZR7KdHhtIC&lpg|accessdate=2 February 2015}}</ref> Declining attendance at Darlington forced its permanent closure in June, 1898<ref name="Thiesen (2006)" /> and Cantonment closed in 1901.<ref name="Dalke (1955)">{{cite journal|last1=Dalke|first1=Herbert M|title=Seventy-five Years of Missions in Oklahoma|journal=Mennonite Life|date=July 1955|volume= X|issue= 3|page=102|url=http://ml.bethelks.edu/store/ml/files/1955jul.pdf|accessdate=3 February 2015|location=North Newton, Kansas}}</ref> In 1908 both the Arapaho Manual Labor and Boarding School and the Cheyenne Manual Labor and Boarding School were closed and the facilities sold by the government.<ref name="P. L. 35 Stat., 88.">{{cite web|title=ACTS OF SIXTIETH CONGRESS—FIRST SESSION, 1908.|url=http://digital.library.okstate.edu/kappler/Vol3/HTML_files/SES0318.html|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> The [[Darlington Agency]] was also closed and relocated to Concho in 1909.<ref name="WPA 1941" />
The new school Concho Boarding School opened in 1909<ref name="Fowler (2010)" /> and re-implemented the farming model, which continued during the [[Great Depression]].<ref name="WPA 1941" /> In 1932 the [[Seger Indian Training School]],<ref name=Seger>{{cite web|title=Colony Public School|url=http://www.abandonedok.com/colony-public-school/|publisher=Abandoned Oklahoma|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> which had incorporated the students of the Red Moon School in 1917,<ref name="Red Moon">{{cite web|title=Department of the Interior. Office of Indian Affairs. Red Moon School and Agency. (12/1909 - 05/16/1917)|url=https://research.archives.gov/organization/1188190|publisher=National Archives|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> closed and its students were transferred to Concho.<ref name=Seger /> Total Concho Boarding School students for 1932 were 133 boys and 117 girls.<ref>Dias (1933), p 12</ref> However, the school struggled during the [[Dust Bowl]] period, where between 1933 and 1937 there were 362 dust storms in the immediate area, coupled with tornadoes and flash flooding. As part of the [[Works Progress Administration]] President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] signed an Executive Order in 1933 which authorized the Indian Service to establish a [[Civilian Conservation Corps]] camp at Concho to improve the grounds and buildings, implement soil erosion controls, and develop water resources.<ref name="Schukies (1993)">{{cite book|last1=Schukies|first1=Renate|title=Red Hat : Cheyenne blue sky maker and keeper of the sacred arrows|date=1993|publisher=Lit Verlag|location=Münster, Hamburg, Germany|isbn=3-89473-585-6|page=246|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y8pPB3sCmMEC&lpg|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> The agency buildings were razed and rebuilt in 1933 and a hospital was constructed in 1941.<ref name="Baird Pt 1(1988)">{{cite journal|last1=Baird|first1=W. David|title=An Historical Overview of the Arapaho Tribe|journal=Historic Context for the Native American Theme Management Region #7: 1803-1938|date=1988|page=211|url=http://www.okhistory.org/shpo/contexts/Region7NativeAmericanPt1.pdf|accessdate=3 February 2015|publisher=Oklahoma State University|location=Stillwater, Oklahoma}}</ref><ref name="Baird Pt 2(1988)">{{cite journal|last1=Baird|first1=W. David|title=An Historical Overview of the Arapaho Tribe|journal=Historic Context for the Native American Theme Management Region #7: 1803-1938|date=1988|page=211|url=http://www.okhistory.org/shpo/contexts/Region7NativeAmericanPt2.pdf|accessdate=3 February 2015|publisher=Oklahoma State University|location=Stillwater, Oklahoma}}</ref>
The era of the federal [[Indian termination policy|Indian Termination Policy]] from the 1940s through the 1960s saw threats to close tribal schools and Concho was not immune. Richard Boynton and George Levi, of the [[Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes]] Business Committee and Robert Goombi of the [[Kiowa]] Tribe of Oklahoma sent pleas to Oklahoma Congressmen to fight school closure.<ref name="Nichols (1992)">{{cite book|last1=Nichols|first1=edited by Roger L.|title=The American Indian : past and present|date=1992|publisher=McGraw-Hill|location=New York|isbn=0-07-046499-5|page=254|edition=4th|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SVcpfdAZ3rEC&lpg}}</ref> The bid to save the school was successful as some of the buildings were converted into a facility to assist troubled students in 1962.<ref name="BIA 1962" /> In 1968, a new school complex was built for the boarding school, featuring a pioneering teaching program which was to be operated in conjunction with [[Southwestern Oklahoma State University|Southwestern State College]]. The program was designed to overcome language and cultural barriers and offer Indian students access to college materials and individual instruction.<ref name="BIA 1968">{{cite web|title=Exemplary Indian School to Open in Oklahoma|url=http://www.bia.gov/cs/groups/public/documents/text/idc017252.pdf|publisher=Department of the Interior Bureau of Indian Affairs|accessdate=3 February 2015|date=July 14, 1968}}</ref>
The school was closed after the graduation ceremonies held 14 May 1982<ref name="Etter (1982)">{{cite news|last1=Etter|first1=Jim|title=Last Graduation Today At Concho Indian School|url=http://newsok.com/last-graduation-today-at-concho-indian-school/article/1983578|accessdate=3 February 2015|publisher=News OK|date=May 14, 1982}}</ref> due to federal budget cuts.<ref name="Brawley (1985)">{{cite news|last1=Brawley|first1=Chris|title=Indians to Use Concho School Buildings|url=http://newsok.com/indians-to-use-concho-school-buildings/article/2097249|accessdate=3 February 2015|publisher=News OK|date=February 6, 1985}}</ref> Though parents and the tribe protested the closure and obtained an injunction to stop it, at the end of the 1983 school term, the school permanently closed.<ref name="Bridgman (1984)">{{cite news|last1=Bridgman|first1=Anne|title=Plan To Shut Indian School Sparks Outcry|url=http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/1984/04/11/05410008.h03.html|accessdate=3 February 2015|publisher=Education Week|date=April 11, 1984}}</ref> The school buildings were returned to the tribe from the BIA in 1985 for use as business enterprises.<ref name="Brawley (1985)" /> In 2015, plans were in the works to convert some of the buildings to a fitness center.<ref name=Watonga>{{cite news|title=Fitness complex design and construction signed|url=http://thewatongarepublican.com/articles/2015/01/28/fitness-complex-design-and-construction-signed|accessdate=3 February 2015|publisher=The Watonga Republican|date=28 January 2015|location=Watonga, Oklahoma}}</ref>
==Concho Demonstration School== In 1962,<ref name="BIA 1962">{{cite web|title=Annual Report of the Secretary of the Interior for the Fiscal Year Ended June 30, 1962|url=http://www.mocavo.com/Annual-Report-of-the-Secretary-of-the-Interior-for-the-Fiscal-Year-Ended-June-30-1962/462614/111|publisher=Bureau of Indian Affairs|accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> a new system for streamlining troubled students back into the school systems was set up. Earl C Intolubbe, a [[Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma|Choctaw]] who was working as an Education Guidance Specialist for the [[Bureau of Indian Affairs]] set up a model school at Concho. The idea was to keep classrooms small so that children received individual attention. Students who had dropped out of other schools were placed in the special program. Some returned within weeks or months to their prior boarding schools or public schools, and some stayed for years. After 6 years of operation, with a 60% success rate, Intolubbe retired in 1968 when it was suggested that the Demonstration School be combined with the Boarding School.<ref name=Intolubbe>{{cite web|last1=Intolubbe|first1=Velma|title=Earl C Intolubbe (Intolabbee)|url=http://www.choctawnation.com/history/people/original-enrollees/intolubbe-earl-c/|website=Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma|publisher=Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma|accessdate=3 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131128052749/http://www.choctawnation.com/history/people/original-enrollees/intolubbe-earl-c/|archivedate=28 November 2013|df=}}</ref>

The '''Council for Scientific Policy''', 1965-1972, was a council set up in the [[United Kingdom]] by the [[secretary of state]]. The council advised the secretary of state on all aspects of his responsibilities with reference to science policy.
== History == The main purpose of the Council for Scientific Policy <ref>{{cite web |url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C829 |title= Council for Scientific Policy |work= The National Archives, United Kingdom|accessdate=July 31, 2017}}</ref> was to advise the government on the resources for science. Before 1965 this advice was given by the [[Advisory Council on Scientific Policy]]. The council was instructed to build a constructive relationship with other research councils, and the [[Ministry of Technology]] and the [[Royal Society]]. The secretariat was run by the [[Department of Education and Science]] (DES).
Chair persons: * 1965 - 1970: Sir [[Harrie Massey]] * 1970 - 1972: Sir [[Frederick Dainton]]
Most members were eminent scientists drawn from universities and industry. A prominent member was [[Derek Barton]] [[Royal Society|FRS]], [[FRSE]] an [[organic chemist]] and [[Nobel Prize laureate]]. Also included were assessors from the [[Medical Research Council (United Kingdom)|Medical Research Council]] and [[Agricultural Research Council]], representatives from Department of Education and Science, [[Department of Scientific and Industrial Research (United Kingdom)|Department of Scientific and Industrial Research]], and the [[University Grants Committee (UK)|University Grants Committee]], the [[Cabinet Office]] and the [[Ministry of Technology]]. The council's primary interest was research, carried out in universities and by the other research councils. The council had a number of committees, sub-committees and working parties. In 1972 the Council for Scientific Policy was wound up and most of its functions passed to the [[Advisory Board for the Research Councils]]. In 1992, responsibility for scientific matters was transferred to the new [[Office of Science and Technology]].
